chapterMeaning: The Yoga of the Division of the Three Gunas
sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम् |
यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः ||१||
transliteration:
śrī bhagavān uvāca |
paraṁ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṁ jñānam uttamam |
yaj jñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṁ siddhim ito gatāḥ ||1||
translation: The Blessed Lord said: I shall again declare to you that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have attained supreme perfection from this world.
commentary:
This opening verse of Chapter 14 marks Krishna's introduction to the profound teaching on the three gunas (qualities of nature): sattva, rajas, and tamas. Krishna emphasizes the supreme importance of this knowledge by calling it 'the best of all knowledge' (jñānām uttamam). This declaration indicates that understanding the gunas is essential for spiritual liberation, as it reveals how prakṛti (material nature) operates and binds the soul.

Krishna validates this teaching by pointing to its results - all the great sages (munayaḥ sarve) who knew this wisdom attained parā siddhi (supreme perfection or liberation). This verse serves as a bridge from the previous chapter's discussion of the kṣetra-kṣetrajña (field and knower of the field) to a more detailed analysis of how the three gunas condition all embodied existence. The knowledge of the gunas is practical wisdom that enables the spiritual aspirant to transcend material conditioning and realize their true nature beyond the influence of prakṛti.
speaker: Krishna
